    Small-Molecule Inhibitors of Necroptosis: Current Status and Perspectives

    • Chunlin Zhuang*
      Chunlin Zhuang
      Engineering Center of Catalysis and Synthesis for Chiral Molecules, Department of Chemistry, Fudan University, Shanghai 200433, China
      Shanghai Engineering Center of Industrial Asymmetric Catalysis for Chiral Drugs, Shanghai 200433, China
      *C.Z.: e-mail, [email protected]
      More by Chunlin Zhuang
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0002-0569-5708
      •  and 
    • Fener Chen*
      Fener Chen
      Engineering Center of Catalysis and Synthesis for Chiral Molecules, Department of Chemistry, Fudan University, Shanghai 200433, China
      Shanghai Engineering Center of Industrial Asymmetric Catalysis for Chiral Drugs, Shanghai 200433, China
      *F.C.: e-mail, [email protected]

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Necroptosis, an important form of programmed cell death (PCD), is a highly regulated caspase-independent type of cell death that plays a critical role in the pathophysiology of various inflammatory, infectious, and degenerative diseases. Currently, receptor-interacting protein kinase 1 (RIPK1), RIPK3, and mixed lineage kinase domain-like protein (MLKL) have been widely recognized as critical therapeutic targets of the necroptotic machinery. Targeting RIPK1, RIPK3, and/or MLKL is a promising strategy for necroptosis-related diseases. Following the identification of the first RIPK1 inhibitor Nec-1 in 2005, the antinecroptosis field is attracting increasing research interest from multiple disciplines, including the biological and medicinal chemistry communities. Herein, we will review the functions of necroptosis in human diseases, as well as the related targets and representative small-molecule inhibitors, mainly focusing on research articles published during the past 10 years. Outlooks and perspectives on the associated challenges are also discussed.

     Note

    This Perspective was published ASAP on October 31, 2019. Structure 48 in Figure 12 and the second-to-last sentence in section 2.1.4. have been updated. The corrected version was reposted on November 20, 2019.

    1. Necroptosis Is an Important Form of Programmed Cell Death

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Apoptosis had long been recognized as the only form of programmed cell death (PCD).(1) An intact plasma membrane with blebbing is considered to be a morphological hallmark of apoptotic cell death.(1,2) Apoptosis is a caspase-dependent noninflammatory form of cell death.(2,3) In contrast to apoptosis, necrosis was considered a form of accidental cell death (ACD) triggered by physical stresses that functioned in a distinct manner for a long time.(4,5) In 1988, Laster et al. reported that tumor necrosis factor (TNF) caused not only apoptosis but also a “balloon-like” plasma membrane boiling form of necrosis.(6) Vercammen et al. found that caspase inhibition favored TNF-induced necrosis in murine L929 cells.(7) These researchers both provided important evidence of nonaccidental programmed necrosis. In the past 30 years, increasing numbers of studies have led to the disclosure that a subset of necrosis, namely, necroptosis, as first described by Yuan et al.,(8) is an important form of PCD. Morphologically, this process is similar to necrosis, showing swelling, ruptured plasma membrane, moderate chromatin condensation, loss of intracellular content, and finally cell lysis.(5,9) For morphological images of apoptosis and necroptosis, a well-reviewed paper by Han et al. should be referenced.(2)
    Necroptosis is now defined as a death-receptor-mediated caspase-independent cell death that triggers inflammation.(3,10−12) The stimulus can be TNF superfamily members, CD95 (FAS), Toll-like receptors 3/4 (TLR3/4), and interferons (IFNs). The TNFα-induced necroptotic mechanism is the best-characterized process to date (Figure 1).(13−16) The homotrimerization of TNF receptor 1 (TNFR1) triggered by TNFα results in the formation of a membrane-signaling complex, namely, complex I, which consists of TNFR1-associated death domain protein (TRADD), TNF receptor 2 (TRAF2), cellular inhibitor of apoptosis proteins 1/2 (cIAP1/2), and receptor-interacting protein kinase 1 (RIPK1).(17,18) Complex I could lead to the activation of prosurvival NF-κB pathway. Under these circumstances, RIPK1 is ubiquitylated by E3 ligases and cIAP1/2, subsequently leading to the activation of NF-κB and cell survival.(19) If the ubiquitination of RIPK1 is prevented by inhibition of cIAP1/2 using second mitochondria-derived activator of caspase (SMAC) or SMAC mimetic chemicals, complex I is released and forms cytoplasmic complex II by recruiting Fas-associated death domain protein (FADD), which mediates the activation of caspase 8.(20,21) Then, apoptosis is in turn triggered by the activation of downstream caspases, such as caspase 3.(22,23) The necrosome containing RIPK1, RIPK3, and mixed lineage kinase domain-like protein (MLKL) is formed in the absence of caspase 8, and the death signals are switched from apoptotic to necrotic. The inhibition of caspase 8 is commonly achieved by z-Val-Ala-Asp-(OMe)-fluoromethyl ketone (z-VAD-FMK).(24,25) Then, the recruited MLKL in necrosomes is phosphorylated by RIPK3, leading to its oligomerization and plasma membrane localization, which is essential for the rupture of the plasma membrane.(26−29) However, the exact mechanism of plasma membrane rupture has not been fully elucidated and needs further investigation.(26−29) The activation of calcium or sodium cation channels and the ion flow to enhance cellular osmotic pressure(27−29) or direct breakdown of the plasma membrane by pore structures of MLKL(26,28) were both reported. Finally, damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) in the cytosol are released through the ruptured plasma membrane, leading to inflammation and organ injury.(30−32)
    Extensive studies have demonstrated that RIPK1, RIPK3, and MLKL are potential therapeutic targets of necroptosis.(33−36) In 2000, a pioneering work by Tschopp et al. reported that RIPK1 was required for necrotic death induced by TNF or TNF-related apoptosis-inducing ligand (TRAIL).(10) In 2005, Yuan et al. reported the first definition of “necroptosis” and the identification of necrostatins as necroptosis inhibitors,(8) which were later shown to target RIPK1, identifying the role of RIPK1 as a key mediator of necroptosis.(37) The discovery of RIPK3 as an essential regulator of TNF-induced necrosis is a key step in disclosing the necroptosis pathway.(33,34,38) Wang et al. reported that RIPK3 knockout mice were resistant to necrosis and devoid of inflammation.(34) A similar study reported that RIPK3 knockout made the mice severely impaired with virus-induced tissue necrosis, inflammation, and control of viral replication.(38) Wang et al. reported a chemical probe that blocked necrosis downstream of RIPK3 activation, which was identified to target MLKL (see section 2.3), a key mediator of necrosis signaling downstream of RIPK3.(35) This result was confirmed by Liu et al. through screening a kinase/phosphatase shRNA library in human colon adenocarcinoma HT-29 cells.(36)
    Strong evidence has suggested that necroptosis has a crucial role in the pathogenesis of various diseases,(39−41) such as ischemia–reperfusion injury,(8,42) neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, ALS; Alzheimer’s disease, AD),(40,43−46) inflammatory diseases (e.g., colitis, pancreatitis, skin inflammation),(31,32,39,47) infectious diseases (e.g., viral infection, bacterial infection),(14,48,49) hepatic and kidney damages,(50,51) and tumor metastasis.(12,52−55) Therefore, the discovery of necroptosis inhibitors will be important for necroptosis-associated diseases and will undoubtedly have broad clinical relevance.

    2. Discovery of Necroptosis Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    On the basis of the human physiological process of necroptosis, a general cell-based necroptosis model has been widely used for drug screening.(56,57) Necrosomes are generated by TNFα or other cytokines, triggering cell death, while SMAC mimetics (commonly SM-164, BV6, or birinapant) inhibit cIAPs(57−61) and z-VAD-FMK blocks the activation of caspase 8. This is known as the TSZ (TNFα-SMAC-z-VAD-FMK)-induced human necroptotic cell model.(32,34,62) This cell model has been used for the discovery of novel necroptosis inhibitors in the following four directions: (1) the discovery of novel active compounds by modern medicinal strategies; (2) drug repurposing of approved drugs; (3) screening of commercial compound libraries and structural optimizations; (4) analysis of natural products. To date, many active compounds have been identified by targeting the key components of necroptosis, RIPK1, RIPK3, and/or MLKL.

    2.1. RIPK1 Inhibitors

    2.1.1. Tryptophan Series

    The discovery of compound 1 (Figure 2), named necrostatin-1 (abbreviated as Nec-1), was a significant milestone in necroptosis research. In 2005, Yuan et al. first reported that 1 bearing a methyl-thiohydantoin-tryptophan (MTH-Trp) scaffold exhibited an EC50 of 490 nM against necroptosis by screening a chemical library of ∼15 000 compounds (Figure 1).(8) Medicinal chemistry analysis later determined the structure–activity relationship (SAR) of Nec-1.(63) Compound 2, without the methyl group on the thiohydantoin, lost the antinecroptosis activity, and nonbranched alkyl groups were suitable at this position. Introducing a chloride to the 7-position of the indole (compound 3) improved the activity to an EC50 of 180 nM. As sulfur limited the metabolic stability of Nec-1 (t1/2 < 5 min in a mouse microsomal assay),(63) replacement of the sulfur on the thiohydantoin by oxygen for compound 4, namely, Nec-1s, maintained the antinecroptotic activity (EC50 = 210 nM). Removal of a carbonyl group to give either a cyclic urea or a carbamate resulted in complete loss of activity. The R-enantiomer (EC50 = 50 nM) was found to be approximately 4-fold more active than the S-enantiomer (EC50 = 230 nM), indicating the importance of the chiral center. The metabolic stability of 4 showed a robust improvement with a t1/2 of approximately 60 min in the liver microsomal assay and an in vivo pharmacokinetics (PK) study.(63) Compound 4 also delayed mouse ischemic brain injury by blocking necroptosis in a dose-dependent manner, providing a novel mechanism for these human pathologies.(8)
    In 2008, Yuan et al. provided definitive evidence for RIPK1 as the target of 1 and its improved analogue 4.(37) The binding mode of Nec with RIPK1 was predicted by homology modeling using B-Raf as the template, which had a very similar conformation to the RIPK1 activation segment. Researchers predicted that the Nec series of inhibitors may target the inactive DLG (Asp-Leu-Gly)-out state of RIPK1. Shi et al. subsequently reported the crystal structures of RIPK1 with Nec-1s and determined the inhibitory constant of 4 (IC50 = 0.32 μM).(64) On the basis of the X-ray complex (Figure 3A), RIPK1 exhibited a canonical kinase fold with a C-lobe, an N-lobe, and an activation loop (highlighted in green). The αC-helix in RIPK1 was rotated by approximately 40° compared with that of the catalytic subunit of protein kinase A (PKA; PDB code 2CPK), and the vacated space was partially occupied by the activation loop and inhibitor 4, locking RIPK1 in an inactive conformation.(64,65) Compound 4 was bound between the lobes near the activation loop and did not interact with the kinase hinge loop, occupying an allosteric lipophilic pocket at the back of the ATP binding site in a type III binding mode. Three specific hydrogen-bonding interactions were observed to anchor the orientation of 4 in the greasy pocket of RIPK1. The interaction between the indole nitrogen atom and the hydroxyl oxygen of S161 on the activation loop was critical to the activity and was confirmed by mutation of S161 to A161 or E161, which led to a 4- or 10-fold decrease in the inhibition. The carbonyl oxygen of V76 and the amide nitrogen of D156 with the five-membered ring of 4 formed two hydrogen bonds. In addition, the indole moiety of 4 interacted with M67, L70, V75, L129, V134, and H136 by van der Waals contacts, and the five-membered hydantoin hydrophobically interacted with V76, L78, L90, M92, L157, L159, and F162 (Figure 3B). The structural analysis provided an explanation for the SAR and offered insights into potential structure-based drug design (SBDD).
    The specificity of the therapeutic target is always a critical issue for kinase-targeting small molecules. From a chemical point of view, the MTH-Trp scaffold of compound 1 has potential inhibitory effects on the immunomodulatory enzyme indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase (IDO) (IC50 ≈ 100 μM).(66,67) The IDO enzymatic assay showed that both compounds 1 and 2 inhibited human IDO with EC50 values of ∼110 nM, while 4 did not inhibit the enzyme at 2000 nM.(67) In addition, compound 4 displayed >1000-fold selectivity toward RIPK1 in a screen of 485 human kinases.(68) Compound 2, the inactive analogue of 1 and 4, still inhibited TNF-induced necroptosis in mouse cells and an in vivo mouse model.(66,67) This observation, to some extent, may reflect species specificity of 2. Vandenabeele et al. proposed that 2 might be converted to a Nec-1-like inhibitory compound by methylation of the thiohydantoin moiety in some cells or even in vivo.(67) However, why compound 2 displays this activity is still not clear. Therefore, compound 2 cannot be used alone as a tool compound to exclude nonspecific off-target effects.

    2.1.2. Benzoxazepinone Series

    In recent years, DNA-encoded library (DEL) screening has been used as a modern robust tool for hit generation in the pharmaceutical industry.(69) GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) utilized their prioritized DEL library to identify novel RIPK1 inhibitor chemotypes (Figure 4).(70,71) Benzo[b][1,4]xazepin-4-one (5) was found to be potent in both a fluorescence polarization (FP) binding assay and an ADP-Glo functional biochemical assay. The chiral amine of benzoxazepinone was determined to have an effect on the activity. The S enantiomer blocked human monocytic U937 necrotic cell death with an IC50 of 200 nM, while the R enantiomer was completely inactive at 10 μM. The results indicated that this molecule was an excellent starting point for optimization due to the good enzymatic and cellular activities and acceptable oral PK profiles (AUC = 2.2 μg·h/mL, Cmax = 810 ng/mL, t1/2 = 2.9 h at a dose of 2 mg/kg). Then, methylation at the NH of benzoxazepinone yielded compound 6 (also known as GSK’481), which showed a 3- or 10-fold increase in the biochemical activity against RIPK1 and excellent translation in the U937 cellular assay with an IC50 of 10 nM. For the target specificity, 6 had a >7500-fold selectivity window at a concentration of 10 μM against 318 kinases of the Reaction Biology Corporation and 456 kinases of DiscoveRx KINOMEscan. However, 6 exhibited low oral exposure (AUC0–∞ = 0.38 μg·h/mL at 2 mg/kg), high clearance (69 mL min–1 kg–1), and high volume of distribution (8.5 L/kg) in rats and was thus probably not suitable for in vivo analysis.(72) Then, the in vivo efficacy was determined for the potent analogue benzodiazepinone 7 (IC50,ADP-Glo,RIPK1 = 0.79 nM), which showed 82% protection at 50 mg/kg against TNF-induced mouse lethal shock and a rat oral bioavailability of 75%.
    Before determination of the binding mode of compound 6 with RIPK1 by cocrystallization, two photolabeling probes were generated by introducing a photolabile trifluoromethyldiazirine moiety at the benzyl ring (8, IC50,FP,RIPK1 = 35 nM) and the 7-position of the benzazepinone heterocycle (9, IC50,FP,RIPK1 = 210 nM). MS/MS sequencing revealed that these molecules labeled the activation-loop residue S161 and the glycine-rich-loop residue F28, respectively, with photoactivation, indicating the potential binding profile as a nonhinge binding kinase inhibitor. This finding was further confirmed by the X-ray structure of the RIPK1 kinase domain with 6 (Figure 5A). The molecule was deeply buried in the pocket between the C-lobe and N-lobe, and no interactions with the hinge residues were observed, confirming the type III binding mode of compound 6. The benzyl group of 6 occupied the same allosteric lipophilic pocket at the back of the ATP binding site as inhibitor 4 surrounded by the D156, S161, and F162 residues. A key hydrogen-bonding interaction was formed by the amide carbonyl with the backbone amide NH of D156. The SAR study indicated that the benzoxazepinone group had a narrow window for optimizations.(72) (1) Replacement of the N-methyl substituent with an ethyl or cyclopropyl group led to a dramatic loss in potency, as it was located at a small pocket on the face of the β-sheet defined by L90 and I43 residues. (2) The S chiral center was important for binding as it orientates the molecule in the activation loop. Increasing the molecule size using a methyl at the chiral center was not tolerated. (3) Methylation of the exocyclic NH or removal of the benzoxazepinone carbonyl led to complete loss of activity. (4) Expanding or contracting the lactam to an eight-membered ring or a quinolinone resulted in a loss of potency. (5) The benzoxazepinone moiety occupied a tight pocket (Figure 5A), indicating a negative effect in altering the oxazepinone conformation. The benzo was an essential group because removal or saturation of the benzo resulted in inactive analogues. Substitutions at the aryl ring were tolerated. (6) The benzyl group was located in an allosteric hydrophobic pocket at the back of the ATP binding site, showing a quite narrow site for optimization. Only fluorine was tolerant at the phenyl ring; removal of the phenyl group and replacement of phenyl with n-butyl, isopropyl, or cyclohexyl groups had negative effects on the activity. (7) The isoxazole heterocycle had a significant effect on potency.
    Compound 10 (also known as GSK2982772) with 1,2,4-triazoles possessed an optimal combination of in vitro potency (IC50,ADP-Glo,RIPK1 = 1.0 nM), low lipophilicity (log D = 3.8), good solubility (∼450 μM at pH 7.4), and rat oral exposure (AUC0–∞ = 2.3 μg·h/mL at 2 mg/kg). Similar to compound 6, compound 10 bound deeply in the pocket in close proximity to the activation loop in the type III binding mode (Figure 5B), giving an explanation of the improved RIPK1 binding activity. The amide carbonyl attached to the triazole formed a direct hydrogen-bonding interaction with the backbone amide NH of D156. A water-mediated hydrogen bond was observed between the carbonyl oxygen of M67 and the triazole nitrogen. With this nonhinge binding mode, compound 10 at a concentration of 10 μM showed a >10 000-fold target specificity based on the RIPK1 ADP-Glo potency of 1 nM against 318 kinases of the Reaction Biology Corporation and 456 kinases of DiscoveRx KINOMEscan. In a mouse TNF-induced shock model, 93% protection at 50 mg/kg and a good PK profile were observed across both rats and monkeys. Currently, this compound has been advanced to phase II trials in patients with chronic immunoinflammatory disorders, such as active ulcerative colitis (NCT02903966), psoriasis (NCT02776033), or moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis (NCT02858492).(73)
    GSK then developed compound 11 (named GSK3145095), which selectively targeted RIPK1 inhibitors (>1500-fold selectivity window), for the treatment of pancreatic cancer.(74) Given the metabolic demethylation of the N-methyl lactam, the methyl was removed, leading to a possible long hydrogen-bonding interaction with L90 (Figure 5C). The 9-fluorine of the benzazepinone occupied a small pocket between M92 and I43. This compound blocked necrotic death in both mouse fibrosarcoma L929 cells (IC50 = 1.3 μM) and human U937 cells (IC50 = 10 nM). A tumor suppressive T cell phenotype in pancreatic adenocarcinoma organ cultures was promoted by the inhibitor treatment, highlighting its potential as a novel cancer therapy. This molecule proceeded to be evaluated alone and in combination with other anticancer agents in phase I clinical evaluations for pancreatic adenocarcinoma and other advanced solid tumors (NCT03681951).
    Takeda Pharmaceutical developed a series of brain-penetrating RIPK1 inhibitors on the basis of a benzoxazepinone scaffold and the initially identified RIPK1 inhibitor 12 (Ki = 63 nM) (Figure 4).(75) The X-ray structure revealed that 12 occupied an allosteric lipophilic pocket at the back of the ATP binding site, did not bind with the hinge region, and interacted with D156 by a hydrogen bond, indicating a very similar binding location to the five-membered heteroaromatic ring of 10 and 12 (Figure 5D). Compound 13 was then obtained by hybridization of these two compounds at the central core structure. The P-gp-mediated efflux (ER = 1.9) was improved compared with that of 10 (ER = 3.1), likely due to the decreased topological polar surface area (TPSA) and the number of hydrogen-bonding donors (HBDs). Further optimizations focused on improving the metabolic stability and blocking the HBD by the SBDD strategy. Compound 14 possessed highly potent activity in vitro (hRIPK1, Ki = 0.91 nM). This compound bound to RIPK1 in a type III kinase inhibitor mode (Figure 5E), leading to a high target specificity against 406 kinases. The new core structure maintained the hydrogen-bonding interaction with D156, and the chloride presumably interacted with M67 by a halogen bond, resulting in the improvement of the binding affinity. In addition, this molecule suppressed necroptotic cell death in both mouse and human cells, possessed good brain-penetrating effects (ER = 0.6) and brain exposure (Cb,u = 0.0230 μg/g), showed metabolic stability in human (<1 μL min–1 mg–1) and mouse (<1 μL min–1 mg–1) liver microsomes and was also effective in an experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) mouse model.
    Genentech recently reported a series of benzoxazepinone analogues with bicyclic heterocycles replacing an aromatic back pocket group.(76) Among them, compound 15 showed promising RIPK1 inhibitory activity (Kiapp = 16 nM) and antinecroptotic activity (EC50,HT-29cell = 130 nM). The X-ray complex revealed that 15 bound to RIPK1 in a similar type III kinase inhibitor mode and that the methyl occupied a similar space as the phenyl ring of 6, suggesting a space for optimization to better fill the pocket. Compound 16 with pentafluoroethyl azaindazole exhibited a Kiapp of 6 nM against RIPK1 and excellent monokinase selectivity with no observed inhibition of >30% at 10 μM against the 219 human kinase panel of Thermo Fisher. The antinecroptotic activity was improved to an EC50 of 54 nM, and the metabolic stability in human (11 mL min–1 kg–1) and rat (14 mL min–1 kg–1) liver microsomes was acceptable. This molecule exhibited low clearance (7.1 mL min–1 kg–1), a moderate volume of distribution (2.8 L/kg), and an oral bioavailability of 63% in rats, encouraging further evaluations. Compound 17 (also known as GNE684) is another bicyclic benzoxazepinone analogue released by Genentech (Figure 6).(54) This compound bound to RIPK1 in a similar ATP back pocket and formed two hydrogen-bonding interactions with D156. Furthermore, the molecule was a potent cross-species RIPK1 inhibitor (Kiapp, human = 21 nM, mouse = 189 nM, rat = 691 nM) and inhibited TNF-induced necroptosis in human HT-29 (EC50 = 6.6 nM), mouse L929 (EC50 = 81 nM), and rat H9c2 (EC50 = 154 nM) cells. The compound showed 100% protection at 5 mg/kg against a TNF-induced systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) mouse model. In addition, it effectively reduced collagen antibody-induced arthritis and prevented skin inflammation caused by mutation of Sharpin or colitis caused by deletion of Nemo from intestinal epithelial cells. However, this molecule did not block tumor growth or death in Kras mutant pancreatic tumor models and did not reduce lung metastases in a B16 melanoma model.(54)

    2.1.3. Dihydropyrazole Series

    In 2015, GSK reported a novel chemotype of dihydropyrazoles by hybridization of two high-throughput screen (HTS) hits 18 and 19, which possessed submicromolar activity in both a RIPK1 FP binding assay and a U937 necroptosis assay (Figure 7).(77,78) The racemic hybrid 20 significantly improved the activity in the nanomolar range. The activity was stereochemical-dependent. The S enantiomer 21 (named GSK’963) was the active form, while compound 22 (named GSK’962), the R enantiomer of 20, was completely inactive at 10 μM. Compound 21 (2 mg/kg, ip) completely inhibited temperature-related loss in response to TNF+zVAD. However, high systematic clearance and low oral exposure in rats (2 mg/kg) were below the limit of detection. For the RIPK1 specificity, 21 showed no additional activity at 10 μM against the 339 kinases of the Reaction Biology Corporation, suggesting a type III binding mode.
    An initial crystal structure was determined for pyrrolidine analogue 23 (Figure 8A). Analyses confirmed that 23 occupied the allosteric pocket in the back of the ATP binding site but did not interact with the kinase hinge region, and the pivaloyl carbonyl formed a hydrogen bond with D156. On the basis of the structural information and limitations of the lead compound 21, an SAR study was performed focused on the dihydropyrazole, phenyl, and tert-butyl fragments.(77) (1) Methyl introduction, reduction, or expansion of the dihydropyrazole ring or thiazoline or azetidine replacement showed decreased or complete loss of the RIPK1 inhibitory potency. (2) On the phenyl ring, small lipophilic groups such as methyl and fluoro were acceptable to maintain potency, but no improvements in clearance were observed (t1/2 < 10 min), while bulkier substitutions reduced the activity. Polar heterocycles and nonpolar cycle replacements of the phenyl ring decreased the potency. (3) On the basis of the binding mode of 23 (Figure 8A), the tert-butyl group pointed to the opening pocket between the N- and C-lobes, suggesting a space for optimization. Compound 24 with a S-N-acetylpiperidine group was both potent and stable in rat and human liver microsomes (t1/2 > 165 min) and showed 22, 43, and 96% protection orally at doses of 1.4, 14, and 140 mg/kg in the TNF/zVAD.fmk-injected mouse model. Further PK and efficacy optimizations identified 25 (also named GSK’547) and 26 with nitrogen-containing heterocycles, occupying the solvent-exposed space at the entrance to the active site pocket (Figure 8B), with good PK profiles in multiple species and satisfactory efficacy in mouse models of both multiple sclerosis and human retinitis pigmentosa. In addition, 25 was applied to determine the efficacy of the RIPK1 inhibitor against pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cancer (PDAC).(79) When mice were treated with 25 and simultaneously challenged with Pdx1Cre, KrasG12D, Trp53R172H (KPC) mouse PDAC tumor cells, which highly expressed RIPK1, the tumor burden and liver metastases were reduced, and mouse survival was extended.

    2.1.4. Other RIPK1 Inhibitors Discovered by HTS or Repurposing

    In 2017, Wang et al. performed a phenotypic screening of a 200 000-compound library in the TSZ-induced HT-29 necroptotic assay.(80) Compound 27 with a benzylamide scaffold was shown to block cell necroptotic death with an EC50 of 4100 nM (Figure 9). A methylated analogue of 27 significantly improved the activity by 10-fold, and 2,3,5-trifluoro substitution on the phenyl ring (28) further improved the potency to 12 nM. However, the liver microsomal stability of 28 in humans (t1/2 = 2.25 min) and mice (t1/2 = 0.75 min) was extremely poor. Changing the methyl to a polar hydroxyl group obtained compound 29 (also named RIPA-56) with an EC50 of 28 nM in HT-29 cells. This change significantly improved the liver microsomal stability to 128 min in humans and 35.5 min in mice. The binding target of 29 was confirmed to be RIPK1 (IC50 = 13 nM). The compound was inactive against RIPK3 at 10 μM, and no inhibition against the Reaction Biology kinase panel at 2 μM was observed, identifying 29 as a type III kinase inhibitor. This compound showed 100% protection at 3 or 6 mg/kg ip in the SIRS mouse model and possessed good oral PK (t1/2 = 3.1 h, F = 22%). A follow-up study by the same group found that the male reproductive organs of wild-type mice blocked the signs of aging for approximately 5 months if the animals were fed food containing 29 prior to the onset of reproductive system aging (13 months), providing evidence for the relationship of necroptosis and male reproductive system aging.(81)
    Repurposing clinically approved drugs or commercial active compound libraries is a widely used strategy in early-stage drug discovery for molecules with strong drug-like properties but lacking target selectivity.(82) Compounds 30–32, as type II RIPK1 inhibitors, were identified by screening the GSK kinase inhibitor library (Figure 10).(83) These molecules have three common structural features:(84) (1) a heterocycle to form hydrogen bonds with the kinase hinge (the fragments highlighted in blue); (2) an aryl moiety to occupy the allosteric hydrophobic pocket (e.g., the 2-F-4-CF3-phenyl group, tert-butylisoxazole); (3) an aryl urea or amide moiety as the linker of the above two parts. The 1-aminoisoquinoline compound 30 had IC50 values of 16 nM (FP) and 10 nM (ADP-Glo) against RIPK1. In a TNF-zVAD.fmk-induced U937 cell model, this compound prevented necrotic cell death with an IC50 of 630 nM. The crystal complex (Figure 10) confirmed the type II binding mode with a DLG-out inactive form of RIPK1, which was different from the inactive conformation observed for RIPK1 with compound 4 (Figure 3) or other type III inihibitors.(64) The 1-aminoisoquinoline was a hinge binder forming hydrogen bonds with M95. The isoxazole heterocycle inserted deeply into the allosteric pocket, and hydrogen bonding interactions occurred between the urea and D156 and E63 to fix the conformation in the DLG motif. Compounds 31 and 32 with changes in the heterocyclic hinge binders both showed good RIPK1 and antinecroptosis activity. However, their kinase selectivity profile showed inhibition of several other kinases at 1 μM against a 300 kinase panel of the Reaction Biology Corporation.
    In 2018, Yang et al. reported a similar series of RIPK1 inhibitors bearing the pyrrolopyrimidine amine scaffold by screening an in-house 20 000-compound library in a TSZ-induced HT-29 cell necroptosis model (Figure 10).(85) Compound 33 had promising antinecroptotic activity with an IC50 of 1450 nM and RIPK1 inhibition with an IC50 of 77 nM. Structural optimizations on the phenylamine, terminal phenyl, and heterocycle regions led to the most active compound, 34, which inhibited RIPK1 with a binding affinity (KD) of 4.4 nM and an enzymatic IC50 value of 11 nM. This compound efficiently protected HT-29 cells from necroptosis with an IC50 of 2 nM and potently protected U937, L929, and J774A.1 cells from necroptosis. Within the RIP kinase family, this compound had >1500-fold selectivity toward RIPK1 over RIPK2, RIPK3, and RIPK4. However, the target selectivity was not outstanding such that some other kinases were inhibited by 34 at 10 μM, which was the limitation of the type II kinase inhibitors. In addition, the compound could effectively inhibit tumor metastasis in a B16 melanoma cell intravenously injected lung metastasis mouse model with favorable PK properties.
    In 2019, from a library of ∼240 compounds, He et al. found compound 35 (PK6) as a novel necroptosis inhibitor with EC50 values of 1200 nM against human HT-29 cells and 760 nM against murine L929 cells (Figure 10).(86) Structural optimizations led to 36 (PK68) containing structural features of sp3 cyclohexane ring and an oxygen between the new ring and amide. The antinecroptotic activity was improved to 23 nM against human HT-29 cells and 13 nM against murine L929 cells. The in vitro kinase assays showed that 35 and 36 both effectively inhibited RIPK1 (IC50 = 200 nM, 90 nM) but did not affect RIPK3 even up to 1000 nM. 36 strongly protected against TNFα-induced SIRS in vivo at the dose of 1 mg/kg, similar to the effect of 35 at 30 mg/kg. In addition, pretreatment of 36 significantly repressed metastasis of melanoma and lung carcinoma cells in mouse models. The PK profile was favorable with an oral bioavailability of 61%.
    In 2015, Superti-Furga et al. reported that a screening of 268 FDA-approved drugs in FADD-deficient Jurkat cells identified two BCR-Abl inhibitors, 37 (ponatinib) and 38 (pazopanib) to effectively block TNFα-induced necroptosis (Figure 11).(57) The antinecroptosis targets of 37 were further revealed by a chemical proteomic approach and validated to be RIPK1, RIPK3, and transforming growth factor-β-activated kinase 1 (TAK1) by multiple assays, while 38 preferentially targeted RIPK1. A similar result was reported earlier by Degterev et al., and they further improved the selectivity of 37 by hybridization with Nec-1.(87) The hinge binding heterocycle part was maintained, and allosteric RIPK1 binding of Nec-1 was introduced by different linkers, of which compound 39 (also named PN10) showed RIPK1 inhibition with an IC50 of 90 nM and no inhibition toward RIPK3 and Abl at 10 μM.
    Two PKR-like ER kinase (PERK) inhibitors, 40 (GSK’414) and 41 (GSK’157), were demonstrated to effectively inhibit TNF-mediated RIPK1-dependent death but did not affect PERK activity in cells.(88) Their antinecroptotic target was proposed to be RIPK1, and they were much more potent than compounds 4 and 21 in both in vitro cell death assays and in vivo TNF-induced SIRS mouse models. This study highlighted the risk of these “selective” PERK inhibitors, and more analogues are needed to obtain specificity for RIPK1 and PERK.
    In addition to the above type II or III RIPK1 inhibitors, compound 42 (tozasertib, VX-680), a type I Aurora kinase (AurK) inhibitor, was reported to have a good affinity against RIPK1 (IC50 = 208 nM).(89,90) Structural optimizations led to compound 43, maintaining RIPK1 inhibitory activity (IC50 = 295 nM) and decreasing AurK activity 3- to 5-fold, with lower cytotoxicity and better anti-SIRS activity than those of 42. The antinecroptosis binding target was confirmed by Meng et al. to be RIPK1. Pretreatment of 43 attenuated cisplatin-induced renal injury and necroptosis in an acute kidney injury mouse model.(91) Another pan-AurK inhibitor, CCT137690, was reported to induce necrosis-like death in PDAC cell lines through RIPK1, RIPK3, and MLKL.(92) Therefore, further investigations are required to determine the exact binding mode of AurK inhibitors with RIPK1, target specificity, and how it affects necroptosis.
    To expand the diversity and address the drug-like properties of the Nec-1 series, Yuan et al. reported other necrostatin compounds (Figure 12), such as 44 (Nec-3),(93,94)45 (Nec-4),(95,96) and 46 (Nec-5),(97) with potent antinecroptotic activity targeting RIPK1.(37) The cocrystal complexes of RIPK1 with a Nec-3 analogue (PDB code 4ITI), 45 (PDB code 4ITJ), revealed a type III binding mode.(64) However, follow-up studies on these novel necrostatins are lacking. Compound 47 was identified as a novel necroptosis inhibitor that prevented retinal degeneration by targeting RIPK1 and did not affect RIPK3.(98) Compound 48 from a noncommercial kinase-focused chemical library was identified to inhibit TNF-induced FADD-deficient Jurkat cell death.(99) RIPK1 was shown to be among the top kinases targeted in a panel of 456 kinases, but other kinases, such as JAK2, PDGFRβ, KIT, and AURKC, were targeted as well, indicating a potential type II binding property. The compound could inhibit RIPK1-dependent necroptosis and apoptosis and protect mice from concanavalin A-induced hepatitis.

    2.1.5. Fluorescent Probes for the RIPK1 Assay

    Two fluorescence-based assays, FP and time-resolved fluorescence resonance energy transfer (TR-FRET), have been developed to determine RIPK1 binding affinity. GSK developed a fluorescently labeled ATP-competitive ligand for the FP assay to compete with a small molecule.(71,72,77) Degterev et al. synthesized two fluorescein-labeled probes based on Nec-1 (compound 49) and Nec-3 (compound 50) for an HTS FP assay (Figure 13).(100) In this assay, the tested DMSO was tolerated up to 5%, and Z′ scores for 49 and 50 were 0.62 and 0.57, respectively. Takeda Pharmaceutical developed the BODIPY probe 51 based on compound 32 for TR-FRET, which was useful to not only measure the binding affinity for RIPK1 but also determine the kinetic profiles of the target compounds.(75)

    2.2. RIPK3 Inhibitors

    On the basis of the mechanism of necroptosis, RIPK3 plays a central role in downstream necroptotic signal events and can signal necroptosis independent of RIPK1.(101) Thus, RIPK3 inhibitors have potential therapeutic relevance in multiple pathological conditions.
    In 2013, Kaiser et al. first identified three RIPK3 inhibitors from the GSK DEL compound library or other conventional small-molecule libraries by FP-binding and ADP-Glo kinase inhibition assays (Figure 14).(102,103) Compound 52 (GSK’840) was shown to have an FP binding IC50 value of 0.9 nM as determined by the ATP-competitive fluorescent probe 55 (GSK’657), which was confirmed by an ADP-Glo RIPK3 kinase assay (IC50 = 0.3 nM). Compounds 53 (GSK’843) and 54 (GSK’872) bound RIPK3 with FP IC50 values of 8.6 nM and 1.8 nM and ADP-Glo kinase IC50 values of 6.5 nM and 1.3 nM, respectively. These molecules also had decent kinase selectivity profiles against a 300-human kinase panel at 1 μM. In human HT-29 cell models, they could dose-dependently block TNF-induced necroptosis. Compounds 53 and 54 were also active in murine cells, but compound 52 was inactive in mouse cells. However, these compounds showed high cytotoxicity and induced RIPK3-dependent apoptosis, which represented a major challenge to the development of anti-inflammatory therapies targeting RIPK3. Green et al. reported 56 (GW’39B) as a RIPK3 inhibitor with an IC50 of 73.6 nM from 8904 bioactive compounds.(104) This molecule could specifically block necroptosis in different cell lines, including SVEC, WT MEF, L929, HeLa, and HT-29 but not NIH-3T3 with RIPK3 lacking the RIP homotypic interaction motif (RHIM) domain. The compound did not block TNF-mediated apoptosis in L929 cells but potentially induced apoptosis. In 2018, Kim et al. discovered compound 57 (namely, HS-1371) as a potent RIPK3 inhibitor (IC50 = 20.8 nM) from an in-house kinase-targeted chemical library.(105) This compound was predicted to bind to the ATP binding pocket of RIPK3 and could protect cells from RIPK3-mediated necroptosis. However, the in vivo efficacy of these compounds has not been reported.
    The drug-repurposing approach was also applied to discover that the B-Raf inhibitor 58 (dabrafenib) inhibited necroptosis by targeting RIPK3 with IC50 values of 250 nM and 2 nM in the luminescent and radioactive assays and showed high selectivity toward RIPK1, RIPK2, and RIPK5 (Figure 15).(106) This molecule inhibited RIPK3-dependent necrosis induced by acetaminophen in human hepatocytes. Importantly, 58 was first reported as a RIPK3 inhibitor to protect mice from hepatotoxicity. Another B-Raf inhibitor, 59 (sorafenib), a poor RIPK3 inhibitor (luminescent IC50 = 14.52 μM), also targeted RIPK1 with an IC50 of 1.5 μM and inhibited in vitro and in vivo necroptosis.(106,107)
    Very recently, another pan-Raf inhibitor, 60 (TAK-632), was identified from an in-house fluorinated compound library generated by our group.(62) This inhibitor was shown to specifically protect against necroptosis in human (HT-29, U937, THP-1) and mouse (L929, J774A.1) cells and did not protect cells from apoptosis. Target identification by drug affinity responsive target stability (DARTS) assays using 60 and a pull-down assay using the less potent biotinylated analogue 61 demonstrated that this inhibitor could bind with RIPK1 and RIPK3 and inhibit their kinase activity with IC50 values of 480 nM and 105 nM, respectively. The results also showed 70% protection at 100 mg/kg and 25% protection at 25 mg/kg against a necroptosis-associated SIRS mouse model. Further SAR analysis led to analogue 62, with only the cyano group removed, which exhibited ∼8-fold better antinecroptotic activity in human HT-29 cells (EC50 = 170 nM) and ∼4-fold and ∼2-fold better in vitro RIPK1 (Kd = 97 nM) and RIPK3 (Kd = 77 nM) kinase inhibition than those of the parent compound.(62,108) Although this molecule showed slight cytotoxicity (CC50 = 36.50 μM), the in vivo anti-SIRS efficacy was markedly improved to 90% and 70% protection at low doses of 50 mg/kg and 25 mg/kg.(62) The SAR also indicated that the carbamide replacement of the amide group led to compound 63 with good antinecroptotic activity and high selectivity for RIPK3 (Kd = 81 nM) over RIPK1 (Kd > 5000 nM).(108) Consistent with the in vitro kinase assay, compound 63 blocked necrosome formation by specifically inhibiting the phosphorylation of RIPK3 in necroptotic cells. Notably, 90% protection of mice from hypothermia and death was observed at a very low dose of 5 mg/kg, and a favorable and drug-like PK property was observed in rats with an oral bioavailability of 25%. However, the Raf inhibitory activity is still a major challenge of these compounds that requires further optimizations.
    Interestingly, the Raf inhibitors (Figure 15) were discovered to possess potential inhibitory activity against RIPK1/3. This finding was believed to result from their strong structural homology.(64,106,109) In addition to the above-mentioned Raf inhibitors, Raf inhibitors such as AZ628, regorafenib, PLX4720, and vemurafenib were reported to inhibit RIPK3 activity with submicromolar IC50 values, but GDC-0879 and SB590885 did not show this activity.(106) However, these compounds, except 58–60, did not rescue TSZ-induced cell death in human HT-29. Thus, more studies are required to investigate the relationships between the Raf and RIP family as well as the in vivo efficacy. Selective inhibitors of RIPK3 targeting the Raf-like compound 63 series may be useful in this aspect.
    Bristol-Myers Squibb identified a series of RIPK3 type II inhibitors by the HTS method (Figure 16).(110) Among the hits, compound 64, a type II c-Met inhibitor, possessed RIPK3 inhibitory activity with an IC50 of 180 nM and good selectivity toward RIPK1 (IC50 = 1.5 μM) and RIPK2 (IC50 > 15 μM). The cocrystal of murine RIPK3 with 64 revealed a DFG-out binding mode. The chemical structure of 64 was rigidified by locking the conformation of pyridone oxygen with the amide. The DFG motif was flipped to form a distal pocket to locate the pyridone and its substituent and form a hydrogen bond with the pyridone oxygen at D161. The azaindole core formed hydrogen-bonding interactions with M98 at the hinge. On the basis of the crystal complex, further linker and hinge binder optimizations led to compound 65 with increased kinase inhibitory activity and selectivity. The RIPK3 potency was improved to 9.1 nM, and c-Met activity was decreased to 1100 nM. However, the activity in human or murine cells and animal models has not been determined yet.

    2.3. MLKL Inhibitors

    Compound 66 (named NSA) was identified to block necroptosis in HT-29 cells by screening a chemical library of ∼200 000 compounds.(35) Biotinylated NSA pulled down human MLKL as the binding target and covalently modified the Michael acceptor at Cys86 (Figure 17). This compound was not active in mouse L929 fibrosarcoma cells because mouse MLKL lacked the corresponding cysteine residue, confirming the target of this compound. Further development of a drug candidate was limited due to the narrow SAR and moderate potency.(111) In the same screening, Wang et al. investigated another hit compound, 67, with good antinecroptosis activity in HT-29 cells (EC50 = 390 nM).(112) This compound did not block the phosphorylation of MLKL but blocked the binding of MLKL to NSA according to the binding competitive experiment. Then, the SAR study led to the highly potent analogue 68 (also termed TC13172, EC50 = 2 nM) with the LC–MS/MS method showing that it covalently bound at Cys86 of MLKL as well. Similarly, this compound was not active in mouse or rat cells. In addition, high cytotoxicity is a major concern when using these covalent inhibitors.
    Silke et al. identified compound 69 (GW806742X) against the recombinant mouse MLKL pseudokinase domain using a thermal stability shift assay of a library of 367 small molecules.(113) This compound showed only a moderate binding affinity with MLKL (Kd = 9.3 μM) and blocked necroptosis in wild-type mouse dermal fibroblasts (MDFs) with an IC50 < 50 nM. A subsequent study disclosed the binding affinity (Kd = 116 nM) and crystal complex with human MLKL (Figure 18).(114) The molecule bound to the ATP-binding site of MLKL, and the amino pyrimidine showed hydrogen-bonding interactions with C286 of the hinge. Hydrogen bonds of the sulfonamide with E293 and urea with G349 and E250 were observed, suggesting a type II binding mode (Figure 18A). However, the compound had an obvious off-target effect against VEGFR2, RIPK1, and RIPK3 (highly nonselective in which 56 out of 403 kinases were inhibited at 1 μM),(113) indicating that MLKL might not be the on-target effect of necroptosis. For identification of compounds that bind to MLKL but not to RIPK1 or RIPK3, compounds 70 (named crizotinib) and 71 were identified.(114) Compound 70 inhibited MLKL (Kd = 210 nM) with 6- to 30-fold selectivity toward RIPK1 or RIPK3. Compound 71 was found to bind to MLKL with high selectivity and no inhibition against RIPK1 and RIPK3 at 30 μM. The cocrystal structure of 71 with the human MLKL pseudokinase domain showed a different binding mode compared with that of 69, indicating a type I MLKL binder (Figure 18B). The compound was located at the ATP binding pocket of MLKL and formed two hydrogen bonds with the hinge C286 and E284 residue. The 4-fluorophenyl formed stacking with R210, and the nonsubstituted phenyl pointed toward the GFE (G349-F350-E351) motif of MLKL but did not displace F350 from its pocket. However, 70 and 71 are limited due to their inactivity against necroptosis in FADD-deficient Jurkat cells. The above information seems reasonable to conclude that pseudokinase-ATP binding pocket may not be necessary for necroptotic activity of MLKL.

    3. Necroptosis Inhibitors in Clinical Development

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Currently, there are at least three necroptosis inhibitors in clinical trials. Compound 10 (GSK2982772) has been advanced into phase I trials (NCT02302404) to test the safety, tolerability, PK, RIPK1 target engagement, and exploratory pharmacodynamics (PD) of single (0.1–120 mg) and repeat (20 mg once daily [q.d.] to up to 120 mg twice daily [b.i.d.]) oral doses for up to 14 days in healthy male subjects.(73) The most common adverse effects were mild contact dermatitis and headache. No deaths or serious adverse effects were identified through vital signs or during physical examinations, neurological examinations, or respiratory assessments. An approximately linear PK was observed over doses up to 120 mg b.i.d. with no apparent accumulation upon repeat dosing. The RIPK1 target engagement achieved >90% over a 24 h period, and a concentration-dependent relationship between the drug candidate and target engagement was observed. No CYP3A4 induction following 14 days of dosing was detected. Phase I/II trials to determine the safety and tolerability, PK, PD, and its efficacy of repeat doses in subjects with moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis (NCT02858492) and psoriasis (NCT02776033) have been completed, but the results have not been posted. Another phase I study to investigate the PK of modified release (MR) prototype-coated tablet formulations of GSK2982772 is recruiting healthy male and female subjects (NCT03649412). Compound 11 (GSK3145095) has been advanced to phase I/II trials alone and in combination with other anticancer agents, including pembrolizumab, in subjects with PDAC and other selected tumors (NCT03681951).
    DNL747, a RIPK1 inhibitor with an undisclosed structure, was reported to show a brain to blood ratio of ∼0.8, which was significantly higher than a benchmark periphery-restricted RIPK1 inhibitor of ∼0.05.(115) Considering the activation of RIPK1 in human AD patient and AD mouse models,(45,46) DNL747 has been advanced to a phase I trial to evaluate the safety, tolerability, PK, and PD of multiple oral doses in subjects with AD (NCT03757325) and ALS (NCT03757351). DNL758, a non-brain-penetrating RIPK1 inhibitor, is in preclinical evaluation for autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis.(115)

    4. Outlook and Future Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The RIPK family contains seven members (RIPK1–7), among which RIPK1, RIPK2, and RIPK3 are largely superimposable with subtle differences in their pharmacologic specificity.(116−118) RIPK1 is the only member of the RIPK family with a C-terminal domain that recruits RIPK1 to signaling complexes to initiate different pathways, including necroptosis, apoptosis, and inflammation (Figure 1).(117,119) Thus, in recent years, RIPK1 has become an important target for drug development not only in the pharmaceutical industry but also in academic research due to its key roles in TNF signaling responses and its highly amenable kinase structure. The type III RIPK1 inhibitors are uniquely selective toward RIPK1.(116,118) The GSK benzoxazepinone and dihydropyrazole compounds showed high selectivity for targeting RIPK1 in the treatment of multiple human diseases in clinical trials.(71,72,74−78) Compounds 1 (Nec-1) and 4 (Nec-1s) have been widely used to define the role of necroptosis and RIPK1 in a few human disease animal models.(120) However, the application of Nec compounds is limited by the moderate potency, stability, and potential off-target effect against IDO.(66,67) Nec-1 only inhibited necroptosis in RIPK1-expressing cells but was inactive against RIPK1-independent necroptosis.(68,121) Compound 60 (TAK-632), a RIPK1 and RIPK3 dual-targeting agent, inhibited RIPK1-independent necroptosis induced by Poly(I:C) plus z-VAD-FMK in RIPK1–/– MEF cells.(62) Mechanistically, RIPK3 can induce necroptosis without RIPK1 in some cases, and in these cases, RIPK1 inhibitors will not work.(101) Thus, selectively targeting RIPK3 has recently attracted attention in the development of inhibitors. However, two concerns are raised in these reported RIPK3 inhibitors. (i) Most of the RIPK3 inhibitors, such as 52–54 and 56, were shown to induce RIPK1-dependent apoptosis.(103,122) (ii) The RIPK family members, especially RIPK2, were reported to be targeted by some RIPK3 inhibitors.(110) For instance, 37 (ponatinib) and 58 (dabrafenib) were shown to be potent inhibitors of RIPK2.(87,106) RIPK2 regulates proinflammatory signaling as a part of nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain (NOD) signaling.(117) A series of RIPK3 type II inhibitors (e.g., compound 65) abolished the RIPK2 activity. However, the developability profiles of the type II kinase inhibitors were challenging due to high molecular weight, high lipophilicity, low aqueous solubility, and a range of off-target kinase activities. Generally, a drug repurposing strategy screened compounds and potentially led to off-target effects, such as pan-Raf inhibitors,(62,106−108) pan-AurK inhibitors,(89,90) PERK inhibitors,(88) BCR-Abl inhibitors,(57,87) which nonselectively inhibited necroptotic targets. Thus, the target selectivity of necroptosis inhibitors, including that for the whole kinome and RIPK family, must be taken into consideration in the current stage.
    Many studies have determined the role of necroptosis in various diseases, especially inflammatory-related diseases.(32) However, the rationale for targeting RIPK1 in cancer, especially pancreatic cancer, is still questionable. Different studies have examined the relationship between necroptosis and tumor metastasis. Yang et al. reported a series of type II RIPK1 inhibitors with the pyrrolopyrimidine amine scaffold (e.g., 33, 34) possessing inhibitory activity against tumor metastasis in a B16 melanoma cell intravenously injected lung metastasis mouse model.(85) GSK reported the RIPK1 inhibitor dihydropyrazole analogue 25 inhibiting PDAC in KPC mice.(77,79) Another mechanistic study also revealed that the necrosome promoted the progression of pancreatic cancer via CXCL1 and Mincle-induced immune suppression.(123) However, a research result from Genentech reported an absolutely different result in which RIPK1 inhibition by small molecules did not block tumor growth or metastases.(54) The Genentech researchers applied two RIPK1 inhibitors, 4 (Nec-1s) and 17 (GNE684), in two autochthonous Kras mutant PDAC models (KPP and KPR) and observed no impact on overall survival or tumor growth and no reduction of lung metastases in a B16 melanoma model. However, pancreatic tumor cell implantation model was used in Yang’s and GSK’s studies, and tumor growth inhibition results were obtained.(77,79,85) Therefore, the difference in these models needs to be further characterized to provide more insight into the relationship between RIPK1 inhibition and tumor growth and metastasis and real effect of RIPK1 on cancer treatment.
    As a key target in the necroptotic pathway, MLKL has attracted increased attention.(35,111−114) Current inhibitors, such as 66–69, were shown to covalently modify MLKL, which might have a high risk of cytotoxicity. Compounds 70 and 71 were shown to bind to MLKL in a type I mode with an obvious off-target effect. In addition, the contribution of MLKL inhibitors in vivo has not been well-defined.
    Collectively, the target specificity of necroptosis inhibitors and whether RIPK1 or RIPK3 represents a priority target for potential intervention are important. The development of animal models with the knock-in of kinase-dead mutants of both RIPK1 and RIPK3 and highly specific chemical tools targeting RIPK1 and/or RIPK3 may help elucidate the exact roles of RIPK1 and RIPK3 in vitro and in vivo. For inhibitor development, the structural biology of RIP kinases, especially that of human RIPK3, which has not been disclosed, and MLKL is critical to SBDD. The catalytic lysines in RIPK1 were proposed to be an alternative site of a reactive cysteine for covalent modification to improve the target selectivity.(124) Natural products are valuable sources with strong biocompatibility.(125) To date, only three cases with unique chemical structures have been reported (Figure 19). Compounds 72 and 73 (named geldanamycins) were reported to protect against neuronal injury induced by oxygen glucose deprivation (OGD)/zVAD treatment and to decrease RIPK1 and Hsp90 protein levels.(126) Shen et al. found a noncanonical Hsp90 inhibitor (74) to block RIPK3-dependent necroptosis in HT-29 cells (IC50 = 200 nM). This molecule was demonstrated to covalently modify Cys420 of Hsp90, leading to the dissociation of Hsp90 from the cochaperone CDC37 to inhibit necroptosis.(127) Compound 75 (known as 6E11) was shown to inhibit necroptosis in Jurkat T cells by selective targeting of RIPK1 (KD = 130 nM).(128) Thus, further analyses of botanical sources, marine sources, microorganism, and other natural sources may provide novel chemical structures and useful biological activities and specificities.(129)
    Combinatorial therapy is a potential area of focus. A RIPK1 inhibitor, GSK3145095, in combination with other anticancer agents, including pembrolizumab, has been proposed in a recent clinical trial (NCT03681951). In addition, combination with other agents targeting different nodes (RIPK1, RIPK3, MLKL) in the necroptotic pathway could also be examined. Alternatively, the development of dual-targeting or multitargeting strategies of the three known targets is a kind of combinatorial therapy that might have clinical advantages.(57,61,62,130) Finally, according to the molecular mechanism of necroptosis (Figure 1), degradation of the targets of necroptosis by the ubiquitin–proteasome system is a reasonable strategy to inhibit the formation of necrosomes.
    In summary, the inhibition of necroptosis has the exciting potential to improve the outcome in a number of inflammatory and degenerative human diseases, as well as possibly a role in oncology. To some extent, the science of necroptosis and its therapeutic targets, as well as the functions and relationships of RIPK1, RIPK3, and MLKL, remains in its infancy. With additional investigations related to structural biology, medicinal chemistry, and mechanisms and preclinical and clinical evaluations of necroptosis-related fields, the clinical future is promising for necroptosis inhibitors.

      accidental cell death

      Alzheimer’s disease

      amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

      Aurora kinase

      cellular inhibitor of apoptosis proteins 1/2

      damage-associated molecular pattern

      drug affinity responsive target stability

      DNA-encoded library

      Fas associated death domain protein

      CD95

      fluorescence polarization

      TAK1

      transforming growth factor-β-activated kinase 1

      TLR3/4

      Toll-like receptors 3/4

      TNF

      tumor necrosis factor

      TNFR1

      TNF receptor 1

      TPSA

      topological polar surface area

      TRADD

      TNFR1-associated death domain protein

      TRAF2

      TNF receptor 2

      TRAIL

      TNF-related apoptosis-inducing ligand

      TR-FRET

      time-resolved fluorescence resonance energy transfer

      TSZ

      TNFα-SMAC-z-VAD-FMK

      z-VAD-FMK

      z-Val-Ala-Asp-(OMe)-fluoromethyl ketone
